bestBHT.bht: After their shipwreck, Paul and his companions arrived at Syracuse, the capital of Sicily, located about 80 miles from Malta. Paul's desire to go ashore in Syracuse, to find out and break ground among the Jews and proselytes whom such a mercantile center would attract, reflects his commitment to spreading the Gospel. Syracuse held historical significance, as Alcibiades had once caused the decline of Athens there. The journey to Syracuse was likely influenced by wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.

Henry Alford: 12.] Syracuse is about eighty miles, a day’s sail, from Malta.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Probably from the state of the wind.
Paul would wish to go ashore, to find out and break ground among the Jews
and proselytes whom such a mercantile center would attract to it.
We cannot wonder that he should be regarded by the Sicilians as the founder of the Church of that island.
Albert Barnes: And landing at Syracuse - Syracuse was the capital of the island of Sicily, on the eastern coast. It was in the direct course from Malta to Rome. It contains about 18,000 inhabitants.
John Calvin: And it is in the country of the Brutians, as is Puteoli, a city of Campania.
But forasmuch as the brethren kept Paul at Puteoli seven days, by this we gather how favorably and gently the centurion handled Paul.
And now we gather out of this place, that the seed of the gospel was then sown abroad, seeing there was some body of the Church even at Puteoli.
Philip Schaff: Landing at Syracuse. Or rather, ‘putting into harbour at Syracuse.’
This was in their direct course. The distance is about eighty miles to the north of Malta.
From what follows, it seems probable that they were waiting for a fair wind.
Archibald T. Robertson: Touching (καταχθεντες). First aorist passive participle of καταγω, to go down to land, just the opposite of ανηχθημεν in verse Acts 28:11 from αναγω, to go up to sea."
At Syracuse (εις Συρακουσας). The chief city of Sicily and eighty miles from Malta.
Here it was that Alcibiades wrecked the power and glory of Athens.
John Gill: Cicero calls it the greatest and most beautiful of all the cities of Greece.
Archimedes...by his invention of warlike machines, baffled all the attempts of the Romans; but was killed by a soldier, as he was intent upon his studies, not knowing that the city was taken.
In this same age lived John, bishop of Syracuse...and Felix a deacon of the same church.

bhtAttempts.bht: After their shipwreck on Malta, Paul and his companions continued their journey towards Rome, stopping at Syracuse, the capital of Sicily. It was about 80 miles away and served as a bustling center attracting Jews and proselytes. This was an opportunity for Paul to engage with the local community and establish connections. Syracuse held historical significance, with Alcibiades having once caused the decline of Athens there. The journey to Syracuse was likely influenced by the wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.

After their shipwreck, Paul and his companions arrived at Syracuse, the capital of Sicily, located about 80 miles from Malta. Paul's desire to go ashore in Syracuse, a thriving city attracting Jews and proselytes, highlights his commitment to spreading the Gospel. Syracuse held historical significance, as Alcibiades had once caused the decline of Athens there. The journey to Syracuse was likely influenced by wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.

Syracuse held historical significance, as Alcibiades had once caused the decline of Athens there. The journey to Syracuse was likely influenced by wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.

Paul would wish to go ashore, to find out and break ground among the Jews and proselytes whom such a mercantile center would attract. Syracuse held historical significance and was known as the greatest and most beautiful of all the cities of Greece. The journey to Syracuse was likely influenced by wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.

After their shipwreck on Malta, Paul and his companions arrived at Syracuse, the capital of Sicily, located about 80 miles away. Paul's desire to go ashore in Syracuse demonstrates his intention to engage with the local community of Jews and proselytes that such a trading city would attract. Syracuse held historical significance, known as the greatest and most beautiful of all the cities of Greece. The journey to Syracuse was influenced by wind conditions, as they had to wait for a fair wind before proceeding.
